Design the Artificial Pacemaker: Use sensors to detect heart rhythms (e.g., pulse sensors). Program a microcontroller (e.g., Arduino) to analyze the heart rhythm and detect irregularities. Use actuators (e.g., small motors or LEDs) to simulate the pacemaker’s electrical impulses. 3. Enhance with Wireless Connectivity: Add a wireless module (e.g., Bluetooth or Wi-Fi) to transmit heart rhythm data to a computer or mobile app. Create a simple interface to display the data and alert doctors if

irregularities are detected. 4. Test and Improve: Test the pacemaker model with simulated heart rhythms (e.g., using a pulse generator or a simple circuit). This study will include: Financial Projections: Estimating startup costs (construction, technology, etc.), operational costs, and potential revenue. Energy Efficiency:

Analyzing how renewable energy (e.g., solar, wind) can power the rides. Market Analysis: Understanding the target audience and competition. Risk Assessment: Identifying potential challenges (e.g., technical issues, weather, safety concerns) and ways to mitigate them. Design Amusement Park Rides:
Rocket Ride: Students will design a rocket ride that uses Newton’s Laws of Motion, particularly the laws of inertia and acceleration, to create thrilling experiences. They will explore concepts like acceleration and force in their design. Ferris Wheel: Students will design a Ferris wheel and study rotational motion to understand how it works. They will explore concepts such as torque and centripetal force. Tora Tora: Students will design a Tora

Tora ride, exploring pressure and speed in a high-speed rotation. They will learn about how forces act on passengers in extreme motion and how to design the ride for both safety and thrill. Integrate Renewable Energy:
Students will research and apply renewable energy sources (such as solar panels or wind turbines) to power their rides. They will explore how energy is converted from renewable sources into usable power for the park. They will create models or simulations to demonstrate how their rides can run on renewable energy and how energy efficiency can be achieved in an amusement park setting. Use Physics Principles:
Newton’s Laws of Motion: First Law (Inertia): The rocket ride and Tora Tora will demonstrate how passengers experience inertia when accelerating or

decelerating rapidly. Second Law (F=ma): Students will calculate the forces involved in the rides and understand how they affect the passengers. Third Law (Action and Reaction): They will explore how the forces exerted by the rocket or Tora Tora ride have equal and opposite reactions. Rotational Motion: Students will analyze the rotational dynamics of the Ferris wheel, including angular velocity, centripetal acceleration, and torque to design a safe and exciting ride. Pressure: In the Tora Tora ride, students will consider how pressure changes within a rotating system, especially regarding the forces passengers experience during high- speed movements.
